name: 黃恩宇
objective: This course explores the history of the ‘modern architecture movement’ taking place primarily in Europe and in the United States from the 19th century to the post-World War II era. During this time, the idea of how architecture and architects should be underwent a radical change, due largely to the massive industrialization, the rapid urbanization and the destructive wars. Most of the architects involved in the modern architecture movement were of the opinion that ‘modern architecture’ should play a role in improving the lives of modern people and in solving the problems caused by the modern society. A number of groups, schools, architects and their works which highlighted and contributed to the modern architecture movement will be introduced in this course
schedule:
Week 1:  An Introduction to the History of Modern Architecture
Week 2:  Architecture in the industrialization and the urbanization of the
19th-century Europe
Week 3:  Structural Rationalism (Henri Labrouste, August Pugin, Eugène
Viollet-le-Duc, Auguste Perret and Hendrik Petrus Berlage)
Week 4:  New Architecture in the United States (Chicago School and Frank
Lloyd Wright)
Week 5:  Art Nouveau in France and Belgium (Hector Guimard, Victor Horta
and Henry van de Velde)
Week 6:  Arts and Crafts Movement in the UK (John Ruskin William Morris,
Augustus Pugin and Charles Rennie Mackintosh)
Week 7:  Day Off
Week 8:  Art Nouveau in Spain (Antoni Gaudí)
Week 9:  Midterm Exam
Week 10: Vienna Secession (Otto Wagner, Joseph Maria Olbrich and Adolf
Loos)
Week 11: Jugendstil and Werkbund in Germany (Henry Van de Velde,
Richard Riemerschmid, August Endell, Josef Hoffmann and Peter
Behrens)
Week 12: De Sijl in the Netherlands (Theo van Doesburg, Piet Mondrian, J. J.
P. Oud and Gerrit Rietveld)
Week 13: Expressionist Architecture (Erich Mendelsohn, Johann Friedrich
Höger, Pieter Kramer, Michel de Klerk, Rudolf Steiner and Josef
Franke)
Week 14: Walter Gropius, Ludwig Mies van der Rohe, Le Corbusier and Alvar
Aalto
Week 15: CIAM (Congrès internationaux d'architecture moderne) between
WWI and WWII
Week 16: TEAM 10 and Structuralism after the WWII
Week 17: Other Important Trends of Architecture after the WWII
Week 18: Final Exam
materials:
List of Readings:

1. Joedicke, Jürgen (1959). A History of Modern Architecture. New York:
Frederick A. Praeger.
2. Frampton, Kenneth (1992). Modern Architecture: A Critical History.
London: Thames & Hudson.
3. Giedion, Sigfried (2009). Space, Time and Architecture: The Growth of a
New Tradition. Cambridge: Harvard University Press.
4. Ibelings, Hans (2011). European Architecture since 1890. Amsterdam:
Sun Publisher.
5. Pevsner, Nikolaus (1986). The Sources of Modern Architecture and
Design. London: Thames & Hudson.
6. Wolfe, Tom (1999). From Bauhaus to Our House. New York: Bantam.
7. Watkin, David (2011). A History of Western Architecture. London:
Laurence King Publishers.
8. Heynen, Hilde (1999). Architecture and Modernity: A Critique. Cambridge: The MIT Press.
